title: Tuesday, 5th December, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Bloody hell, eh?

BE11:03am

Today's portrait is:

BE11:03am

11:03 am
BE11:03am

As per Politico:

BE11:03am

U.K. negotiators confirmed that a TV appearance by the party’s leader Arlene Foster — in which she declared “any form of regulatory divergence” separating Northern Ireland from the mainland was unacceptable — torpedoed the talks, but did not support the claim that she effectively threatened to bring down the government.
Asked what caused the deal to collapse, one very senior U.K. negotiator said: “Look at what Arlene Foster said this PM.” A senior British aide simply texted an emoji of a crying face.

BE11:03am

https://www.politi...-trip-to-brussels/

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Anyway, latest on the wires is that talks between the DUP and the UK are "ongoing below leader level" with May and thingmy ... Arlene thingmy, having "not scheduled a meeting at this point".

BE11:05am

Sterling's two day view looks like a heart attack, of course.

BE11:06am

FTSE flat in £ terms and down in proper currencies.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

I could chuck some macroside analysis up here but, frankly, what's the point?

undefined
BE11:08am

So instead, to corporate.

11:08 am
Provident Financial PLC (PFG:LSE): Last: 770.50, down 109.5 (-12.44%), High: 819.00, Low: 704.50, Volume: 2.07m
BE11:08am

FCA's decided that he only bit of Provident that looked okay is probably not okay.

BE11:09am

As in, Moneybarn. Car lending.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

FCA's started an investigation “in relation to the processes applied to customer affordability assessments for vehicle finance and the treatment of customers in financial difficulties.”

BE11:10am

Note that Moneybarn only got FCA approval on June 3rd, 2016

BE11:11am

And as the statement says, "since that date the FCA has continued to discuss certain processes with Moneybarn and Moneybarn has made a number of process improvements, including to the way it deals with future loan terminations."

11:11 am
BE11:12am

This adds to the FCA's investegation into the Vanquis’ Repayment Option Plan, which isn't PPI in spite of looking very very very very like PPI.

BE11:12am

Plus the massive screwup made of the doorstep credit side

BE11:13am

You have to imagine that a Provident rights issue isn't a wild impossibility here.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Though whether shareholders would back it is another question. Not sure I'd want to be the one to ask Woodford to double down.

BE11:14am

Here's Citi for the background.

BE11:15am

It is important to note that ‘authorization’ does not necessarily mean that the FCA is 100% comfortable with a business’s operations and that it is not unusual for an ongoing dialogue to be maintained, therefore. Moneybarn was made aware of the investigation yesterday via a letter. There is no timeframe, nor has the FCA brought evidence of malpractice.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Given the other issues that the company is having to deal with at present, including home credit’s turnaround and the investigation into the ROP product sold at Vanquis, today’s announcement could be a storm in a teacup. The board may feel that it needs to disclose issues as soon as they come across their desk. However, on the other hand, it could be an indication of some serious failings at Moneybarn which it has failed to deal with properly. We believe that it is more likely to be the former. There is no trigger for dialogue with the FCA to turn into an investigation and, therefore, we do not think that Moneybarn is guilty of not heeding FCA opinions and/or advice.

BE11:16am

The Opportunity to Press Reset – The uncertainty around Moneybarn, coupled with Vanquis, will spook investors. The question for the medium term is what this does to the company’s reputation and how it is able to fix it. Provident is searching for a new CEO and a new Chairman. This provides the company with an excellent opportunity to press the reset button and change its messaging, but what impact will these events have on recruitment? Which comes first: the Chairman or the CEO? We suspect it will be the latter. Given the recent investigations, getting back into the FCA’s good books will surely feature on the incoming CEO’s ‘to do list’ underlined, in bold and with a red asterisk next to it.

BE11:17am

And RBC.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

What we had previously described as “the one bright spot, but the smallest part of the company” following the Q3/17 IMS is now under investigation by the FCA, to accompany the FCA’s ongoing investigation into Vanquis’ Repayment Option Plan as well as the troubled restructuring and stunted recovery of the Consumer Credit Division. Further, we maintain that upcoming debt repayments, likely FCA
redress at Vanquis, ongoing losses, potential goodwill and intangible write offs (which could be exacerbated by today’s announcement) and the negative impact of IFRS 9 will result in a stretched balance sheet and the potential need for additional equity capital in the future

BE11:19am

And James Hamilton at Numis.

BE11:20am

Moneybarn made an operating profit
of £31m last year out of a total of £334m. We expect further process change as a consequence of this but this is not expected to substantially change group profit, but sentiment is expected to be negatively impacted in the short term.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

He's still very keen on knife catching here.

BE11:20am

We believe that Home Collected Credit (HCC) and Vanquis are category killers, holding dominant market positions with sustainable competitive advantage in high margin, high return businesses, which means that they can maintain the greatest economic profit in the specialist lenders sub-sector. With a targeted 20% CET1 ratio, HCC and Vanquis made ROAEs of 73% and 55%, respectively, last year.

BE11:21am

With the No.2 provider having the capacity to take a maximum of less than 3% of Provident's HCC business, we believe only Provident can substantially reduce its scale. We believe the HCC business can be turned around and very high returns restored even if the business is much smaller. Morses achieved a RoA of 17.9% last year (Provident’s HCC RoA was 18.2% last year) from a loan book that is just 12% of Provident's.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

I mean, okay, it's a potential recovery play. I get that.

BE11:22am

But it has no CEO, no chairman, and no money.

BE11:23am

There are lower risk gambles to take.

11:22 am
undefined
BE11:23am

And so to Cineworld ......

Cineworld Group PLC (CINE:LSE): Last: 532.50, down 13.5 (-2.47%), High: 557.00, Low: 520.50, Volume: 1.24m
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Which has pulled the trigger on this reverse takeover of America's second biggest and rather efficiently run cinema operator.

BE11:24am

Details include a $75m break fee if another buyer appears

BE11:25am

Lowered to $36.3m if a buyer appears before the go-shop.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And raised to $95.2m on a simple termination.

BE11:27am

Deal funded through a £1.7bn rights issue and $4.0bn from new debt facilities.

BE11:28am

Which brings Cineworld to -- yeah, really -- pro-forma net debt of 4.0 times 2017 EBITDA.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Deal still needs a majority shareholder vote

BE11:29am

Though Global City Holdings, on 28 per cent, makes that highly likely to go through.

BE11:30am

Here's what the rights issue looks like if we assume 546p.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

BE11:31am

That's via Citi, which also states the obvious ....

BE11:31am

The acquisition expands Cineworld’s scope and provides opportunity to
achieve substantial synergy benefits. However, the acquisition also materially
changes Cineworlds investment proposition with a greater degree of mature market exposure and a heavily geared balance sheet which may add constraint to future investment demands.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Note the stuff in the statement about maintaining a progressive dividend policy, incidentally. The cost of debt to fund that payout looks a nonsense to me, but hey whatever.

BE11:33am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:34am

We estimate [$23 a share] this equates to paying 8.7x EBITDA (2018E) to buy into a very mature market. As a result of $150m of targeted
synergies/structural benefits and Cineworld’s net debt/EBITDA rising from c1x to c4x (£1.7bn of
extra equity; almost £3bn of extra debt), we estimate this should
enhance earnings by c30%. However, the long-term equity story has changed, with higher debt and reduced growth prospects.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

P/E of 24.1x 2017E and 21.7x 2018E.

BE11:35am

Cineworld itself is on 13x.

BE11:36am

I guess we should note, while we're here, AMC.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Which is America's other cinema rollup, funded out of China, highly leveraged and sending out all sorts of distress signals as it creaks badly.

BE11:38am

I'd guess that part of Cineworld's attraction to Regal is based on a keen understanding of what'll happen next to AMC. But beyond that it's probably best for me not to speculate.

BE11:38am

Here's Canaccord.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

We believe the timing is brilliant and do not expect a rival bid nor any regulatory issues; however, we believe the (reverse) acquisition is fraught with execution risk. The other concern for Cineworld shareholders is that, post-deal, Cineworld assumes Regal's undisturbed valuation - and not the other way round. Using the last undisturbed share price, Regal's share price has fallen by 7.7% since its IPO in May 2002.

BE11:02am

And also, good morning. Welcome to Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily w'ev.

BE11:40am

.... which is another oddity here.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Back to Canaccord.

BE11:41am

The acquisition implies EV of 8.0x FY17E which compares well to recent transactions with a range of 9x-12x EV/EBITDA multiples. AMC (under Wanda) had previously led the consolidation charge until Chinese regulators halted state-owned banks from lending to Wanda to finance foreign entertainment acquisitions. AMC acquired Odeon for £921m in
July 2016. AMC is 80% owned by Wanda which has a long-term ambition to control 20% of the global film market. AMC also acquired Carmike for US $1.2bn, the No. 4 US chain, in December 2016. Since then, AMC has snapped up Nordic Cinemas Group for £750m in January 2017.

BE11:42am

The bigger story that will play out over the next year or so, I speculate, will involve Cineworld and Regal and AMC and Wanda and mystery SWFs.

11:42 am
undefined
BE11:44am

Somewhere back there among the comments, someone mentioned Tesco.

Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 202.75, up 7.6 (+3.89%), High: 203.75, Low: 199.75, Volume: 21.24m
11:44 am
BE11:44am

This is Goldman flipping from sell to buy.

BE11:44am

Sector thing.

BE11:46am

Which I guess is very big, as it's taking forever to open.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Bingo! Yes, 60 pages worth.

BE11:46am

Margin pressure in the UK grocery market is easing. Competitive intensity is still high, but multiple datapoints suggest 2018 will see greater industry margin expansion than 2017 After four years with a Sell rating, we upgrade Tesco to Buy. Since being added to the Sell list on November 13, 2013, the stock is down 46.4% vs. FTSE World Europe +24.7%. We upgrade Morrisons to Neutral, increase our price target on Sainsbury, but remain Sell rated, and downgrade Booker to Neutral.

J Sainsbury PLC (SBRY:LSE): Last: 240.20, up 7.3 (+3.13%), High: 240.30, Low: 234.40, Volume: 3.84m
11:46 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 220.10, up 6.1 (+2.85%), High: 222.80, Low: 217.30, Volume: 3.36m
Booker Group PLC (BOK:LSE): Last: 223.30, up 4.1 (+1.87%), High: 225.00, Low: 218.30, Volume: 2.90m
BE11:47am

So .....

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Falling input cost inflation and less aggressive pricing strategy by discounters than during the last inflationary spike mean the gap between input costs and consumer food prices (CPI) is now at its narrowest in over a year. Coupled with falling fuel prices and wages tracking below food CPI for the first time in four years, we see a more constructive margin environment in UK grocery in 2018 vs 2017 While we are positive at the margin, we still believe the UK is a structurally challenged market and forecast long-term EBIT margins and returns well below pre-2014 levels.

BE11:48am

And ..........

BE11:48am

While Tesco is still passing through less inflation than its Big 4 peers, the data
suggests it has stopped inflating below the overall market since August 2017 Scale and a superior cost savings programme mean we forecast Tesco can continue taking share from the Big 4, supporting LFL growth, while reinvesting cost savings at a lower level than in 1H18. This should drive greater margin expansion than we
forecast before and our FY18-20 EBIT estimates are up 5%-17.5%. While not included in our valuation, we present a detailed analysis of potential synergies from the proposed Booker merger, highlighting that we estimate FCF/share accretion could be in the range of -2% to +33% in FY21E. We upgrade Tesco to Buy.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Below the line, there's some interesting stuff.

BE11:49am

BE11:49am

What do you usually call it when five dominant suppliers change their prices in lockstep?

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Think it begins with a C. Oh well, never mind.

undefined
BE11:53am

What else we got going on here?

11:53 am
BE11:53am

There's bloody Fever Tree, or bloody Fevertree if you prefer. Can never remember whether the company has the space in its name or the brand.

Fevertree Drinks PLC (FEVR:LSE): Last: 1,951, up 11 (+0.57%), High: 1,981, Low: 1,935, Volume: 80.28k
BE11:54am

Anyway, it's taking tonic water to America

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Where they must still mix their gin with ... U dunno, ditch water or Gatorade or something.

BE11:55am

Fever-Tree, the world’s leading supplier of premium carbonated mixers, is pleased to announce the establishment of a North American office and the appointment of Charles Gibb as the Group’s North American CEO.

Since Fever-Tree first entered the North American market 10 years ago, its pioneering approach to taste and quality of ingredients has seen the Group become the number one premium mixer brand in the US. Today’s announcement is the next step forward, signalling Fever-Tree’s commitment to and focus on the North American market. The US premium mixer sector continues to represent a significant opportunity for the Group given the existence of the same trends of premiumisation, authenticity and mixability that have been driving the success of Fever-Tree globally.

BE11:55am

Does this change anything? Clearly, obviously, not.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Is it another opportunity for Fevertree buyers to say "buy"? Clearly, obviously, yes.

BE11:56am

Here's Investec.

BE11:56am

Fever-Tree has announced a change to its sales and distribution arrangements in the USA. Since its entry into this market, 10 years ago, it has worked with Brands of Britain, which has acted as its agent in the US, managing the group’s relationships with key distributors and retailers. This has been a successful arrangement to date and has resulted in Fever-Tree establishing a solid presence in both channels. Fever-Tree is the US’s #1 brand in premium mixers.
However, the Board now believes the time is right to transition this function back in-house, in order to secure more control and to drive the opportunity the group believes is present in this market, given the presence of the same trends that have been driving Fever-Tree’s growth globally. It has thus given notice to Brands of Britain (BoB).

11:56 am
BE11:57am

It will work closely with BoB for the next six months whilst also establishing its own US operation under the leadership of Charles Gibb. Charles joined Fever-Tree in August 2017 and he will be the group’s North American CEO. He will spend the next 6 months building his team to ensure a smooth hand-over from BoB in Q2 18. Charles has a well-established background in managing brands having worked at Moet Hennessy, Diageo and Bacardi. His most recent role (past 9 years) was as President and CEO of Belvedere Vodka, where he was responsible for the brand’s substantial global expansion.
We see no implications for our forecasts. BoB agent’s fee will be replaced by direct overhead. Whilst these will likely (initially) exceed the agent fee, we believe this is accommodated in our estimate that FY18E opex expenses will be c22% of revenues.

BE11:58am

And Shore, who are not buyers.

BE11:58am

We believe today’s announcement is a positive step forward for Fever-Tree albeit it does not suggest a change to our forecasts at this stage both in terms of revenue and costs. We note notice has been given to Brands of Britain, its US distributor partnership and a formal handover is to be completed in Q2 2018. Although not stated in the release we would anticipate in-market production to be forthcoming within the next 18-24 months too (through a partner).

In terms of valuation Fever-Tree, following the recent upgrades, trades on a FY2017F PER of 51.9x with an EV/EBITDA ratio of 39.1x and a 0.6% yield. We believe the valuation remains full and therefore, we retain our HOLD recommendation.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

60x. Sure. Why not.

undefined
BE12:00pm

Yeah, okay, Iomart.

12:00 pm
iomart group PLC (IOM:LSE): Last: 390.00, up 17 (+4.56%), High: 390.00, Low: 375.00, Volume: 81.81k
BE12:01pm

........ though I haven't even glanced at the interims.

BE12:01pm

But they're fine, according to Finncap.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

iomart has delivered interims which demonstrate their typical mix of organic and acquired growth, leading to mild net upgrades to revenue (FY18: +1% and FY19: +3%) and EBITDA (+2% and +5%), while net debt of £24.5m is still comfortably below 1x annualised EBITDA. The ongoing acquisition of skills and customers is leading to development of further revenue streams, and development of iomart's reputation as specialist in multiple fields and verticals (for example cloud back-up as a niche expertise, and e-commerce as a vertical specialisation). The cloud market opportunity remains strong and growing, given the complexity of the delivery of reliable cloud services, whether private, public, or hybrid. iomart continues to deliver consistent growth, strong margins, and predictable cash, with an attractive cash flow yield and a supportive dividend illustrating board confidence. With forecasts upgraded, we lift our target price to 415p, equivalent to an unchallenging 10x FY19 EV/EBITDA.

BE12:02pm

And, oh, Panmure.

BE12:03pm

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Sorry for the screengrab, they blocked ctrl-C on the PDF.

BE12:04pm

And Peel Hunt.

BE12:05pm

The group continues to benefit from the structural growth of the cloud economy by focusing on transactional, mission-critical, and largely web-facing, private cloud hosting opportunities. This was evident in the 1H18 results, where the growth (org cloud hosting is +8%) and the margin (cloud hosting adj EBITDA is 44.6%) contained no surprises. Therefore, we leave our earnings forecasts largely unchanged. In recent months, the company has made two acquisitions to better target online retail businesses, a clear growth area, and has invested to future-proof its network infrastructure. Both strategic steps are in line with what we have come to appreciate from iomart. Given its structural sweet-spot in a world obsessed with the Cloud, its 10% adj EBITDA CAGR over the forecast period and the underlying FCF/EBITDA rate of 50%, we remain fans of the story and reiterate our Buy rating. iomart trades on cal 18 EV/EBITDA of 9.6x, a discount to the peer group on 13x.

12:05 pm
undefined
BE12:06pm

Not doing IG for one simple reason ....

BE12:06pm

12:06 pm
BE12:07pm

... and, ROTR, why in God's name are you talking about silicon wafers again?

BE12:07pm

I'm going to close this to save you from yourself.

BE12:07pm

Thanks for all the comments.

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Back tomorrow.

BE12:08pm

Afternoon all.

BE12:09pm

(ROTR: the Aim cryptobunkum thing is: https://www.invest...&tab=announcements )

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

(And DYOR, ROTR. As they used to say on the bulletin boards that pump this nonsense.)

BE12:10pm

Right. Really closing now. Go away.

BE11:40am

@SoS: yep, unnamed SWF going in with Global City to allow it to fully take up its rights ....
